description:
'''Industrial music''' (or simply '''industrial''') is a [[subgenre]] of [[experimental music]]  inspired by [[post-industrial society]], initially drawing influences from [[avant-garde music|avant-garde]] and early [[electronic music]] genres such as [[musique concrète]], [[tape music]], [[Noise music|noise]] and [[sound collage]].  The term was coined in 1976 by [[Monte Cazazza]] and adopted by [[Throbbing Gristle]] with the founding of [[Industrial Records]]. Other early industrial musicians include [[Boyd Rice|NON]] and [[Cabaret Voltaire (band)|Cabaret Voltaire]]. By the late 1970s, additional artists emerged such as [[Clock DVA]], [[Nocturnal Emissions]], [[Einstürzende Neubauten]], [[SPK (band)|SPK]], [[Nurse with Wound]], and [[Z'EV|Z’EV]], alongside [[Whitehouse (band)|Whitehouse]] who coined the subgenre "[[Power electronics (music genre)|power electronics]]".

During the 1980s, industrial music splintered into a range of offshoots collectively labelled "[[Post-industrial (music)|post-industrial music]]", these included, [[EBM music|EBM]], [[new beat]], [[new beat|hard beat]], [[dark ambient]], [[neofolk]], [[power noise]], [[industrial dance]], [[electro-industrial]], [[dark electro]], [[aggrotech]], [[industrial rock]], [[industrial metal]], [[cyber metal]], [[Neue Deutsche Härte]], [[martial industrial]], [[industrial hip-hop]] and [[industrial techno]]. By the 1990s, elements of industrial music were made accessible to mainstream audiences through the popularity of acts such as [[Nine Inch Nails]], [[Ministry (band)|Ministry]], [[Rammstein]], and [[Marilyn Manson (band)|Marilyn Manson]], all of whom released platinum-selling records.
